Question 178 An input to a 6-level quantizer has the probability density function f(x) as shown in the figure. Decision boundaries of the quantizer are chosen so as t maximize the entropy of the quantizer output. It is given that 3 consecutive decision
boundaries are '-1', '0' and '1' . Assuming that the reconstruction levels of the quantizer are the mid-points of
the decision boundaries, the ratio of signal power to quantization noise power is
solution: Signal power, [latex] \begin{aligned} S &=E\left[X^{2}\right]=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} x^{2} f_{X}(x) d x \\ &=2\left[\int_{0}^{1} a x^{2} d x+\int_{1}^{5} b x^{2} d x\right]=2\left[a\left(\frac{x^{3}}{3}\right)^{1}+b\left(\frac{x^{3}}{3}\right)^{5}\right]_{1} \\ &=2\left[\frac{a}{3}+\frac{124 b}{3}\right]=2\left[\frac{1}{6 \times 3}+\frac{124}{12 \times 3}\right]=7 \end{aligned} [/latex] Quantization noise power, [latex] \begin{aligned} N_{Q}&=\sum_{i=1}^{2} \frac{\Delta_{i}^{2}}{12} P\left(\Delta_{i}\right) \\ \Delta_{1}&=1 \vee ; \\ for 1 \lt x \lt 1 \\ \Delta_{2}&=2 V ; \\ for 1 \lt |x| \lt 5 \\ P\left(\Delta_{1}\right)&=P\{-1 \lt x \lt 1\}=2 a=\frac{1}{3} \\ P\left(\Delta_{2}\right)&=1-P\left(\Delta_{1}\right)=\frac{2}{3} \\ So, N_{Q}&=\frac{1}{3}\left(\frac{1^{2}}{12}\right)+\frac{2}{3}\left(\frac{2^{2}}{12}\right)=\frac{1}{4} \\ \text{Hence, SQNR}&=\frac{S}{N_{Q}}=28 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 179 An input to a 6-level quantizer has the probability density function f(x) as shown in the figure. Decision boundaries of the quantizer are chosen so as t maximize the entropy of the quantizer output. It is given that 3 consecutive decision
boundaries are '-1', '0' and '1' . The values of a and b are
solution: To maximize the entropy, all the decision boundaries should be equiprobable [latex]\begin{aligned} \int_{1}^{5} \rho_{x}(x) d x&=\frac{1}{3}\\ \int_{1}^{5} b d x&=\frac{1}{3} \\ b|x|_{1}^{5}&=\frac{1}{3} \\ b[5-1]&=\frac{1}{3} \\ 4 b&=\frac{1}{3} \\ b&=\frac{1}{12} \\ \int_{-1}^{1} p_{x}(x) d x&=\frac{1}{3}\\ \int_{-1}^{1} a d x &=\frac{1}{3} \\ a[x]_{-1}^{1} &=\frac{1}{3} \\ a[1-(-1)] &=\frac{1}{3} \\ 2 a &=\frac{1}{3} \Rightarrow a=\frac{1}{6} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 186 The raised cosine pulse p(t) is used for zero ISI in digital communications. The
expression for p(t) with unity roll-off factor is given by [latex]p(t)=\frac{sin4 \pi Wt}{4\pi Wt(1-16 W^{2}t^{2})}[/latex]. The value of p(t) at [latex]t=\frac{1}{4W}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \rho(t) &=\frac{\sin 4 \pi \omega t}{4 \pi M\left(1-16 W^{2} t^{2}\right)} \\ \rho\left(\frac{1}{4 W}\right) &=\frac{\sin 4 \pi W \times \frac{1}{4 W}}{4 \pi W \times \frac{1}{4 W}\left(1-16 W^{2} \frac{1}{16 W^{2}}\right)} \end{aligned}[/latex] As it comes in the form of 0/0 so applying LH rule [latex] \begin{aligned} P\left(\frac{1}{4 W}\right)&=\frac{\frac{d}{d t} \sin 4 \pi w t}{\frac{d}{d t} 4 \pi W t\left(1-16 W^{2} t^{2}\right)} \\ &=\frac{\cos 4 \pi w t}{1-48 W^{2} t^{2}} \\ \text { Putting } \quad t &=\frac{1}{4 \mathrm{W}} \\ P(t) &=\frac{\cos \pi}{1-3}=0.5 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 218 A random variable X with uniform density in the interval 0 to 1 is quantized as
follows : If 0 [latex]\leq[/latex] X [latex]\leq[/latex] 0.3,  [latex]x_{q}[/latex] = 0 If 0.3 [latex]\lt[/latex] X [latex]\leq[/latex] 1, [latex]x_{q}[/latex] = 0.7 where [latex]x_{q}[/latex] is the quantized value of X. The root-mean square value of the quantization noise is
solution: [latex]Q_{e}=\mathrm{s.v.}-\mathrm{q} \cdot \mathrm{v}=x-x_{q} [/latex] Mean square value of quantization noise [latex] \begin{array}{l} =E\left[\left(x-x_{q}\right)^{2}\right] \\ =\int_{0}^{1}\left(x-x_{q}\right)^{2} f_{X}(x) d x \\ =\int_{0}^{1}\left(x-x_{q}\right)^{2} \cdot 1 d x \\ \int_{0}^{0.3}(x-0)^{2} d x+\int_{0.3}^{1}(x-0.7)^{2} d x \\ =0.039 \end{array}[/latex] Root mean square value of the quantization arise [latex] =\sqrt{0.039}=0.198[/latex]

question:
Question 219 Consider a binary digital communication system with equally likely 0's and 1's. When binary 0 is transmitted the detector input can lie between the levels -0.25 V and +0.25 V with equl probability : when binary 1 is transmitted, the voltage at the detector can have any value between 0 and 1 V with equal probability. If the detector has a threshold of 0.2 V (i.e., if the received signal is
greater than 0.2 V, the bit is taken as 1), the average bit error probability is
solution: Shaded areas show the probability of error. [latex]\begin{aligned} P_e(0)&=\frac{\text{error}}{\text{total}}\\ &=\frac{0.25-2}{0.25-(-0.25)}\\ P_e(1)&=\frac{0.2-0}{1-0}=0.2 \end{aligned}[/latex] Since probability of occurrences of 0 and 1 are equal [latex]Avg.=\frac{P_e(0)+P_e(1)}{2}=0.15[/latex]

continuous sinusoidal signal is a periodic Every singnal [latex]
\begin{array}{c}
s(t)=A \cos [2 \pi \times 10 K t]+A \cos [2 \pi \times 10.1 K t] \\

\frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}=\text { Rational }
\end{array}[/latex] [latex]
\therefore s(t)[/latex] will be periodic with period LCM  of [latex]
T_{1} \& T_{2}=9900 \mu \mathrm{s} ; 10,000 \mu \mathrm{s}[/latex] [latex]
\therefore [/latex] Frequency =0.1 kHz Resulting is a sinusoidal signal with frequency 
0.1 kHz. Frequency detector converts frequency 
variations to equivalent of voltage variations. 
Because signal has constant frequency of

question: Question 221 A 100 MHz carrier of 1 V amplitude and a 1 MHz modulating signal of 1 V amplitude are fed to a balanced modulator. The ourput of the modulator is passed through an ideal high-pass filter with cut-off frequency of 100 MHz. The output of the filter is added with 100 MHz signal of 1 V amplitude and 90[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] phase shift as shown in the figure. The envelope of the resultant signal is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} y(t)=\frac{1}{2} \cos \left\{2 \pi \times 101 \times 10^{6}\right\} t+\sin 2 \pi \times 100+10^{6} t \\ =\frac{1}{2}\left[\cos \left(2 \pi 100 \times 10^{6}\right) t \cos 10^{6} t \cdot 2 \pi-\sin \left(2 \pi \times 100 \times 10^{6}\right)\right. \\ t \sin 2 \pi 10^{6} t+\sin 2 \pi \times 100 \times 10^{6} t \\ =\frac{1}{2} \cos 2 \pi \times 100 \times 10^{6} t\left[\cos 2 \pi \times 10^{6} t\right] \\ +\frac{1}{2} \sin 2 \pi \times 100 \times 10^{6} t\left[-\sin 2 \pi \times 10^{6} t+2\right] \\ =A \cos 2 \pi \times 10^{6} t+B \sin \cos 2 \pi \times 10^{6} t \\ \end{array}[/latex] Envelope [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\sqrt{A^{2}+B^{2}} \\ =\sqrt{\frac{1}{4} \cos ^{2} 2 \pi \times 10^{6} t+\frac{1}{4}\left[\sin 2 \pi \times 10^{6} t-2\right]} \end{array}[/latex] Envelope [latex] =\sqrt{\frac{5}{4}-\sin (2 \pi \times 10^{6} t)}[/latex]

question: Question 222 A 1 mW video signal having a bandwidth of 100 MHz is transmitted to a receiver through cable that has 40 dB loss. If the effective one-side noise spectral density at the receiver is [latex]10^{-20}[/latex] Watt/Hz, then the signal-to-noise ratio at the receiver is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{SNR} &=\frac{P_{s}}{N_{0} B} \\ &=\frac{10^{-3}}{10^{-20} \times 100 \times 10^{6}}=10^{9} \\ (\mathrm{SNR})_{\mathrm{dB}} &=10 \log 10^{9}=90 \mathrm{dB} \\ \text { Cable loss } &=40 \mathrm{dB}\\ \therefore \quad \text{ SNR at }R_{x}&=(90-40) d B=50 \mathrm{dB} \end{aligned}\\[/latex]

question: Question 224 In the output of a DM speech encoder, the consecutive pulses are of opposite polarity during time interval [latex]t_{1}\leq 1\leq t_{2}[/latex]. This indicates that during this interval

In between the two adjacent sampled values, if

indicated that the base band is almost constant.

question: Question 225 An AM signal and a narrow-band FM signal with identical carriers, modulating signals and modulation indices of 0.1 are added together. The resultant signal can be closely approximated by
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{c} s(t)=A_{c} \cos \omega_{c} t+\frac{A_{c} \beta}{2} \cos \left(\omega_{c}+\omega_{m}\right) t \\ -\frac{A_{c} \beta}{2} \cos \left(\omega_{c}-\omega_{m}\right) \\ s(t)_{A M}=A_{c} \cos \omega_{c} t+\frac{A_{c} m_{a}}{2} \\ \cos \left(\omega_{c}+\omega_{m}\right) t+\frac{A_{c} m_{a}}{2} \cos \left(\omega_{c}-\omega_{m}\right) \\ s(t)+s(t)_{A M}=\text { carrier }+\cup S B \\ =S S B \text { with carrier. } \\ \text { Note: }-s(t)+s(t)_{A M}=S S B+S C \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 231 If S represents the carrier synchronization at the receiver and [latex]\rho[/latex] represents the bandwidth efficiency, then the correct statement for the coherent binary PSK is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Bandwidth efficiency }&=\frac{1}{T_{b} \times B W}\\ \text{For BPSK.}\qquad B W&=\frac{1}{T_{b}} \end{aligned}[/latex] (with Nyquist pulse shaping of baseband data) So. Bandwidth efficiency =1

question: Question 232 The input to a linear delta modulator having a step-size [latex]\Delta[/latex]=0.628 is a sine wave with frequency [latex]f_{m}[/latex] and peak amplitude [latex]E_{m}[/latex]. If the sampling frequency [latex]f_{s}[/latex]=40 kHz, the combination of the sine-wave frequency and the peak amplitude, where slope overload will take place is
solution: For slope overload to take place, [latex] \begin{array}{l} \frac{\Delta}{T_{s}} \leq A_{m} \omega_{m} \\ \frac{\Delta}{T_{s}}=0.628 \times 40 \times 10^{3} \\ =25120=25.12 \mathrm{K} \end{array}[/latex] Matching with options [latex]2 \pi \times 1.5 \times 4 \mathrm{K}=37.7 \text{ which  is greater than  } \Delta / T_{s}[/latex]

question: Question 233 If [latex]E_{b}[/latex], the energy per bit of a binary digital signal, is [latex]10^{-6}[/latex] watt-sec and the one-sided power spectral density of the white noise, [latex]N_{0}=10^{-5}[/latex] W/Hz, then the output SNR of the matched filter is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{SNR} &=\frac{2 E_{\mathrm{b}}}{N_{0}}=\frac{2 \times 10^{-5}}{10^{-6}}=20 \\ (\mathrm{SNR})_{\mathrm{dB}} &=10 \log 20=13 \mathrm{dB} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 234 A sinusoidal signal with peak-to-peak amplitude of 1.536 V is quantized into 128 levels using a mid-rise uniform quantizer. The quantization-noise power is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta&=\frac{2 M_{p}}{L}=\frac{1.536}{128} \\ P_{N}&=\frac{\Delta^{2}}{12}=\frac{\left(\frac{1.536}{128}\right)^{2}}{12}=12 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{V}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 235 A superheterodyne receiver is to operate in the frequency range 550 kHz - 1650 kHz, with the intermediate frequency of 450 kHz. Let R = [latex]C_{max}/C_{min}[/latex] denote the required capacitance ratio of the local oscillator and I denote the image frequency (in kHz) of the incoming signal. If the receiver is tuned to 700 kHz, then
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} R &=\frac{C_{\max }}{C_{\min }}=\left(\frac{f_{\max }}{f_{\min }}\right)^{2}=\left(\frac{1650+450}{550+450}\right)^{2} \\ &=4.41 \\ I &=f_{s}+2 f_{i f}=700+2 \times 450=1600 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 236 Choose the correct one from among the alternative A,B,C,D after matching an item in Group 1 with most appropriate item in Group 2.

Question 237 Let [latex]m(t)=\cos [(4\pi \times 10^{3})t][/latex] be the message signal & [latex]c(t)=5\cos [(2\pi \times 10^{6}t)][/latex] be the carrier. c(t) and m(t) are used to generated an FM signal. If the peak frequency deviation of the generated FM signal is three times the transmission bandwidth of the AM signal, then the coefficient of the term [latex]\cos [{2\pi (1008\times 10^{3}t)}][/latex] in the FM signal (in terms of the Bessel coefficients) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x_{\mathrm{F}} \cdot(f) &=A_{c} \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} J_{n}(\beta) \cos \left(\omega_{c}+n \omega_{m}\right) t \\ E \cdot \mathrm{W} \cdot &=2 \omega_{m} \\ \Delta \omega &=3 \times \mathrm{BW}=6 \omega_{m} \\ \beta &=\frac{\Delta \omega}{\omega_{m}}=6 \\ \therefore \quad \quad \omega_{c}+r \omega_{m} &=2 \pi \times 1008 \times 10^{3}\\ &\qquad(\text{given in question}) \\ \therefore\quad 2 \pi \times 10^{6}&+n .4 \pi \times 10^{3}=2 \pi \times 1008 \times 10^{3} \\ \therefore \quad n&=4 \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Bessel coefficient [latex]5 J_{4}(6)[/latex]

question: Question 238 Let [latex]m(t)=\cos [(4\pi \times 10^{3})t][/latex] be the message signal and [latex]c(t)=5\cos [(2\pi \times 10^{6}t)][/latex] be the carrier. c(t) and m(t) are used to generate an AM signal. The modulation index of the generated AM signal is 0.5. Then the quantity [latex]\frac{Total \; sideband \; power}{Carrier \; power}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{c} P_{t}=P_{c}\left(1+\frac{m_{a}^{2}}{2}\right) \\ P_{c}=\frac{A_{c}^{2}}{2} \\ \text { Sideband power }=\frac{A_{c}^{2}}{2} \cdot \frac{m_{a}^{2}}{2} \\ \therefore \quad \frac{P_{s}}{P_{c}}=\frac{\left(\frac{A_{c}^{2} m_{a}^{2}}{4}\right)}{\left(\frac{A_{c}^{2}}{2}\right)}=\frac{m_{a}^{2}}{2}=\frac{1}{8} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 239 A DSB-SC signal is to be generated with a carrier frequency [latex]f_{c}[/latex] = 1 MHz using anon-linear device with the input-output characteristic [latex]V_{0}=a_{0}v_{i}+a_{1}v_{i}^{3}[/latex] where [latex]a_{0}[/latex] and [latex]a_{1}[/latex] are constants. The output of the non-linear device can be filtered by an appropriate band pass filter. Let [latex]V_{i}=A_{c}^{'}\cos (2\pi f_{c}'t)+m(t)[/latex], where m(t) is the message signal. Then the value of [latex]f_{c}^{'}[/latex] (in MHz) is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} V_{0}=a_{0} v_{i}+a_{1} v_{i}^{3}\\ =a_{0}\left(A_{c}^{i} \cos \omega_{c}^{i} t\right)+a_{d} m(t)+a_{1} A_{c}^{3} \cos ^{3}\left(n_{c}^{i} t\right. \\ +a_{1} m^{3}(t)+3 a_{3} m^{2}(t) A_{c}^{i} \cos \omega_{c}^{i} t \\ +3 a_{1} A_{c}^{\prime} \cos ^{2} \omega_{c}^{i} t m(t) \end{array}[/latex] For DSB-SC, we are concerned with only last term. [latex] \begin{aligned} m(t) \cos \omega_{c} t \rightarrow f_{c} &=1 \mathrm{MHz} \\ \text { For } \cos ^{2} \text { term, } 2 \omega_{c}^{i} &=2 \pi \times 1 \mathrm{MHz} \\ \cos ^{2} \text { term, } 2 \omega_{c}^{i} &=2 \pi \times 1 \mathrm{MHz} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 240 X(t) is a random process with a constant mean value of 2 and the auto correlation function [latex]R_{x}(\tau )=4(e^{-0.2\left | \tau \right |}+1)[/latex]. Let Y and Z be the random variable obtained by sampling X(t) at t=2 and t=4 respectively. Let W=Y-Z. The variance of W is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} W &=Y-Z \\ \sigma_{w}^{2} &=E\left[\gamma^{2}\right]+E\left[Z^{2}\right]-2 E[Y \cdot Z] \\ \text{Y is sampled }&\text{at t=2 and Z at t=4}\\ \therefore \quad \sigma_{W}^{2}&=\sigma_{Y}^{2}+\sigma_{Z}^{2}-2 R_{x x}(2) \\ &=8+8-2\left[4 e^{-0.212 t}+1\right] \\ \Rightarrow \quad \sigma_{W}^{2} &=2.64 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 241 X(t) is a random process with a constant mean value of 2 and the auto correlation function [latex]R_{x}(\tau )=4(e^{-0.2\left | \tau \right |}+1)[/latex]. Let X be the Gaussian random variable obtained by sampling the process at [latex]t =t_{i}[/latex] and let [latex]Q\left ( \alpha \right )=\int_{\alpha }^{\infty }-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi }}e^{\frac{y^{2}}{2}dy}[/latex] The probability that [latex]\left | X\leq 1 \right |[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} R_{XX}(\tau) &=4\left[e^{-0.2|\tau|}+1\right] \\ P(X \leq 1) &=F_{x}(1) \\ &=1-Q\left(\frac{x-\mu}{\sigma}\right) \text { at } x=1 \\ \mu &=0, \text { given } \\ A_{x}(0) &=\sigma^{2} \\ \sigma^{2} &=8 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \sigma &=2 \sqrt{2}\\ \therefore \quad P(x \leq 1) &=1-Q\left(\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2}}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 242 Let X and Y be two statistically independent random variables uniformly distributed in the ranges (-1,1) and (-2,1) respectively. Let Z=X+Y. Then the probability that (Z [latex]\leq[/latex]-1) is
solution: [latex]\Rightarrow \quad K^{11}=\frac{1}{6} [/latex] since it lies in middle of [latex]\frac{1}{3} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \text{Prob}[z \leq-2] \\ & =\text { Area of graph }[z \leq-2] \\ &=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{1}{6} \times 1=\frac{1}{12} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 243 At a given probability of error, binary coherent FSK is inferior to binary coherent PSK by.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{e(\mathrm{BPSW})}&=Q(\sqrt{\frac{2 E_{\mathrm{BPSK}}}{N_{0}}}) \\ P_{e(\mathrm{BFSK})}&=Q(\sqrt{\frac{E_{\mathrm{BFSK}}}{N_{0}}}) \end{aligned}[/latex] To get same probability of error in both the schemes. [latex] \begin{aligned} 2 E_{B P S K}&=E_{\theta F S K} \\ \frac{E_{B F S K}}{E_{B P S K}}&=2(\text { or }) 3 \mathrm{dB} \end{aligned}[/latex] So, at a given probability of error, coherent BFSK  is inferior to coherent BPSK by 3 dB

question:
Question 246 If the variance [latex]\sigma _{x}^{2}[/latex] of d(n)=x(n)-x(n-1) is one-tenth the variance
[latex]\sigma _{x}^{2}[/latex] of a stationary zero mean discrete time signal x(n), then the normalized autocorrelation function [latex]\frac{R_{xx}(k)}{\sigma _{x}^{2}}[/latex] at k=1 is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} E\left[d^{2}(n)\right]=E\left[\{x(n)-x(n-1)\}^{2}\right] \\ \sigma_{d}^{2}=E[x(n)]^{2}+E[x(n-1)]^{2}-2 E[x(n) x(n-1)] \\ \Rightarrow \frac{\sigma_{X}^{2}}{10}=\sigma_{X}^{2}+\sigma_{X}^{2}-2 R_{X X}(1) \rightarrow \end{array}[/latex] Auto correlation at, k=1 [latex] \begin{aligned} 2 R_{x x}(1)&=\frac{19}{10} \sigma_{x}^{2} \\ \therefore \quad \frac{R_{x x}(1)}{\sigma_{x}^{2}}&=\frac{19}{20}=0.95 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 247 A signal [latex]x(t) = 100 cos(24\pi \times 10^{3})t[/latex] is ideally sampled with a sampling period of 50
[latex]\mu[/latex]sec and then passed through an ideal low-pass filter with cutoff frequency of 15
KHz. Which of the following frequencies is/are present at the filter output?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} 50 \mu \mathrm{s} \Rightarrow 20 \mathrm{kHz} & \\ f_{m}=& 12 \mathrm{kHz}\\ f_{s}=&20 \mathrm{k} \; \mathrm{ samples/sec} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Frequency at filter output with cut-off frequency of 15 k is [latex]20 \pm 12=8 \mathrm{kHz}[/latex] and [latex]f_{m}=12 \mathrm{kHz}[/latex]

question: Question 248 In the figure, [latex]m(t)=\frac{2\sin 2\pi t}{t}[/latex], [latex]s(t)=\cos 200\pi t[/latex] and [latex] n(t)=\frac{\sin 199\pi t}{t}[/latex]. The output y(t) will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} m(t) \times s(t) &=\frac{2 \sin 2 \pi t}{t} \times \cos 200 \pi t \\ &=\frac{1}{t}(\sin 202 \pi t-\sin 198 \pi t) \end{aligned} [/latex] The signal at the input of the LPF will be, [latex] x(t)=[m(t) s(t)+n(t)] s(t) [/latex] [latex] =\frac{1}{t}(\sin 202 \pi t-\sin 198 \pi t+\sin 199 \pi t) \cos 200 \pi t [/latex] [latex] =\frac{1}{2 t}(\sin 402 \pi t+\sin 399 \pi t-\sin 398 \pi t) [/latex] [latex] \quad+\frac{1}{2 t}(\sin 2 \pi t+\sin 2 \pi t-\sin \pi t) [/latex] After passing [latex]\frac{1}{2 t}(\sin 402 \pi t+\sin 399 \pi t-\sin 398 \pi t) [/latex]  term through LPF with cut-off frequency of 1 Hz , it results in a component of [latex]\frac{1}{2 t}(\sin 2 \pi t)[/latex] at the output. So, after passing x(t) through the LPF, we get, [latex] \begin{aligned} y(t) &=\frac{1}{2 t}(\sin 2 \pi t)+\frac{1}{2 t}(\sin 2 \pi t+\sin 2 \pi t-\sin \pi t) \\ &=\frac{\sin 2 \pi t}{t}+\frac{1}{2 t}(2 \sin 0.5 \pi t \cos 1.5 \pi t) \\ y(t) &=\frac{\sin 2 \pi t}{t}+\frac{\sin 0.5 \pi t}{t} \cos 1.5 \pi t \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 249 An angle modulated signal is given by [latex]s(t)=cos2\pi (2\times 10^{6}t+30 sin 150t+40 cos 150t)[/latex] The maximum frequency and phase deviations of s(t) are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} s(t) &=\cos [2 \pi \times 2 \times 10^{6} t+2 \pi \times 30 \sin 150 t \\&+2 \pi \times 40 \cos 150 t] \\ \frac{d \phi}{d t} &=2 \pi \times 2 \times 10^{6}\\ & +2 \pi \times 4500 \cos 150 t+2 \pi \times 6000(-\sin 150 t) \\ \therefore \Delta \omega &=\omega_{1}-\omega_{c}=2 \pi\left(4500^{2}+6000^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} \\ &=2 \pi \times 7.5 \mathrm{k} \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec} \\ \therefore \quad \Delta f &=\frac{\Delta \omega}{2 \pi}=7.5 \mathrm{kHz} \\ \Delta \phi &=2 \pi \sqrt{30^{2}+40^{2}} \\ \Delta \phi &=100 \pi \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 251 Consider a sample signal [latex] y(t)=5 \times 10^{-6} x(t) \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} \delta (t-nT_s)[/latex] where [latex]x(t)=10 \cos (8 \pi \times 10^3)t[/latex] and [latex]T_s=100 \mu sec[/latex]. When y(t) is passed through an ideal low-pass filter with a cutoff frequency of 5 KHz, the output of the filter is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Y(f)&=\frac{5 \times 10^{-6}}{100 \times 10^{-6}} \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} X\left(f-n f_{s}\right) \\ f_{s}&=\frac{1}{T_{s}}=10 \mathrm{kHz} \end{aligned}[/latex] x(t) is a sinusoidal signal of 4 kHz since [latex]f_{s} \gt 8 \mathrm{kHz}[/latex] and cut-off frequency [latex]f_{c}[/latex] of the LPF satisfies [latex]4 \mathrm{kHz} \lt \left(f_{c}=5 \mathrm{kHz}\right) \lt 6 \mathrm{kHz}[/latex] , the output signal of the filter will be [latex] \begin{aligned} z(t) &=\frac{1}{20} x(t)=\frac{10}{20} \cos \left(8 \pi \times 10^{3} t\right) \\ &=5 \times 10^{-1} \cos \left(8 \pi \times 10^{3} t\right) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
